skill.name: api-mitmproxy
skill.description: Interactive HTTPS proxy for API security testing with traffic interception, modification, and replay capabilities. Supports HTTP/1, HTTP/2, HTTP/3, WebSockets, and TLS-protected protocols. Includes Python scripting API for automation and multiple interfaces (console, web, CLI). Use when: (1) Intercepting and analyzing API traffic for security testing, (2) Modifying HTTP/HTTPS requests and responses to test API behavior, (3) Recording and replaying API traffic for testing, (4) Debugging mobile app or thick client API communications, (5) Automating API security tests with Python scripts, (6) Exporting traffic in HAR format for analysis.
skill.summary: Interactive HTTPS proxy for API security testing with traffic interception, modification, and replay...
skill.author: AgentSecOps

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill describing mitmproxy, a legitimate open-source security tool. Contains no executable scripts. Includes security considerations for proper authorization and sensitive data handling. Content is defensive and educational.

content.user_title: Test API Security with HTTPS Proxy
content.value_statement: API security testing requires intercepting and analyzing HTTPS traffic. This skill provides guidance on using mitmproxy to inspect, modify, and replay API traffic for security testing. Perfect for penetration testers and developers who need to identify vulnerabilities in API implementations.
actual_capabilities: Intercept and inspect HTTPS API traffic in real-time
Modify HTTP requests and responses to test API behavior
Automate security tests with Python scripting API
Record and replay API traffic sessions
Test mobile app API communications through proxy
Export traffic captures in HAR format for analysis
limitations: Does not install or execute mitmproxy - users must install tool separately
Does not perform automated vulnerability scanning
Does not generate security reports or findings
Requires external mitmproxy installation (pip install mitmproxy)

use_cases.title: API vulnerability assessment
use_cases.description: Intercept and modify API traffic to identify authorization flaws, injection vulnerabilities, and business logic issues.

use_cases.title: Mobile app API analysis
use_cases.description: Test iOS and Android application API communications by routing traffic through mitmproxy for deep inspection.

use_cases.title: Automated API security testing
use_cases.description: Create Python scripts using mitmproxy API to automate security tests and integrate with CI/CD pipelines.

prompt_templates.title: Quick API inspection
prompt_templates.scenario: Start mitmproxy for manual API testing
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I use mitmproxy to intercept and inspect API traffic for security testing? Show me the quick start commands.

prompt_templates.title: Authentication testing
prompt_templates.prompt: How can I use mitmproxy to test API authentication? Show me examples of capturing and manipulating authentication tokens.

prompt_templates.title: Parameter fuzzing
prompt_templates.scenario: Fuzz API parameters for injection testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a mitmproxy Python script to fuzz API parameters for SQL injection and XSS vulnerabilities. Show the scripting approach.

prompt_templates.title: Mobile app testing
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I configure mitmproxy for mobile app API security testing? Include certificate installation and SSL pinning bypass approaches.

output_examples.input: How do I test API authorization using mitmproxy?
output: 3. Install mitmproxy CA certificate on device
- Modify user IDs in requests to test IDOR
- Remove authorization headers to test authentication
- Escalate privileges by changing role headers
- Replay requests with different user contexts
5. Python script example for authorization testing:
Important: Only test systems you own or have explicit authorization to test.

best_practices: Always obtain explicit authorization before intercepting traffic on any system you do not own
Install mitmproxy CA certificates securely and remove them after testing sessions
Encrypt and securely store any captured traffic that may contain credentials or sensitive data
anti_patterns: Never intercept production traffic without proper authorization and data protection measures
Do not commit flow files or captured traffic to version control systems
Avoid testing against third-party APIs without explicit permission from the API provider

faq.question: What operating systems does mitmproxy support?
faq.answer: mitmproxy runs on Linux, macOS, and Windows. Install via pip (pip install mitmproxy) or download binaries from mitmproxy.org.

faq.question: Does this skill install mitmproxy?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides documentation and guidance. Users must install mitmproxy separately using pip install mitmproxy.

faq.question: Can I test HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 APIs?
faq.answer: Yes, mitmproxy supports HTTP/2 natively. HTTP/3 support is available experimentally with the --http3 flag.

faq.question: How do I handle apps with SSL pinning?
faq.answer: SSL pinning requires additional tools like Frida for Android or SSL Kill Switch for iOS to bypass certificate validation.

faq.question: Is captured traffic encrypted?
faq.answer: Traffic captured by mitmproxy is decrypted for inspection. Store flow files securely and never commit them to version control.

faq.question: How is this different from Burp Suite?
faq.answer: mitmproxy is open-source and CLI-focused with Python scripting. Burp Suite provides a graphical interface with more built-in testing features but requires a commercial license for full functionality.
